title: 107_s930
content:
The Grand Canyon Capital Improvements Act of 2001 establishes definitions for terms like fundraising organization, memorandum of agreement, Park, and Secretary. It also outlines the creation of a fundraising organization and the use of bond proceeds for improvements in the Grand Canyon National Park. The Secretary can enter into a memorandum of agreement with a fundraising organization to issue taxable bonds for the Park's benefit. The organization must adhere to professional standards, undergo audits, and the US is not liable for the bonds. The fundraising organization must enter into a memorandum of agreement detailing the bond issue, maturity not exceeding 20 years, per capita amount for bond repayment and administration costs, funded projects at the Park, and procedures for agreement modifications. The Secretary may authorize the Superintendent of the Park to charge a surcharge of up to $2 per individual in addition to entrance fees collected under various programs. The Secretary may authorize a surcharge of up to $2 per individual in addition to entrance fees collected under certain programs. The total amount charged may not exceed $2 per individual. The surcharge must be used to amortize bond issues, cover administration costs, and maintain a reserve as determined by the bond underwriter. SEC. 6. USE OF BOND PROCEEDS.

Bond proceeds can be used for projects in the Park, following specific limitations and not for administrative expenses. Interest earned can cover reserve requirements and administrative expenses related to bond management and sale.

SEC. 7. REPORT. The Secretary must submit a report to Congress within 2 years of regulations being issued, reviewing the bond program at the Park and providing recommendations on establishing a bond program at all units of the National Park System. The Secretary, in consultation with the Secretary of Treasury, will promulgate regulations to implement the Act.
